Identifying Characteristics: Color is variable, depending on habitat
Dark, wavy, worm-like line along back
Leading edges of fins are white, including the tail
Biology: Female constructs a depression (redd) in the stream bed where groundwater percolates upward through the gravel
Eggs are fertilized by one or more males as they are expressed by the female
Female buries the eggs in a small gravel mound; eggs hatch in 95 to 100 days
Adult size: varies greatly, depending on water temperature, productivity, and food sources
Statewide average length of 3 year-old brook trout in Maine lakes is 13.3 inches, but in some lakes may reach 17.5 inches in length
Stream populations are typically slower growing than lake populations
Diet: Larval, pupal, and adult forms of aquatic insects (e.g., caddisflies, stoneflies, mayflies and aquatic dipterans)
Adult forms of terrestrial insects (e.g., ants, beetles, grasshoppers and crickets) that fall into the water
Small aquatic mammals such as voles
Habitat: Prefer clear, cool waters of high purity and a narrow pH range; preferred pH - 5.0 to 7.5
Range: Native Range: Eastern North America in the US and Canada
